title: R41355
content: The U.S. Department of Education released a Blueprint for reforming the Elementary and Secondary Education Act, which is the main source of federal aid for K-12 education. The Blueprint builds on existing reforms and funding initiatives from the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act. The Blueprint for reforming the Elementary and Secondary Education Act focuses on key priorities such as College- and Career-Ready Students and Great Teachers and Leaders in Every School. It includes funding programs like the State Fiscal Stabilization Fund, Race to the Top Program, and Investing in Innovation Fund. The Blueprint for reforming the Elementary and Secondary Education Act outlines key priorities including College- and Career-Ready Students, Great Teachers and Leaders in Every School, Equity and Opportunity for All Students, Raise the Bar and Reward Excellence, and Promote Innovation and Continuous Improvement. These priorities focus on effective teachers and principals, equitable resource distribution, accountability, student success, and fostering innovation. The Blueprint discusses these priorities in detail, emphasizing the importance of achieving these goals through various initiatives. The Blueprint for reforming the Elementary and Secondary Education Act outlines key priorities including College- and Career-Ready Students, Great Teachers and Leaders in Every School, Equity and Opportunity for All Students, Raise the Bar and Reward Excellence, and Promote Innovation and Continuous Improvement. The topics discussed in the Blueprint are not consistently organized in the same order as the priorities, and details of the reauthorization proposal vary in depth. The Blueprint is seen as a starting point for discussions on ESEA reauthorization. The report prepared in response to congressional demand maps the proposals in the Blueprint for ESEA reauthorization. It relies on the Blueprint and other sources to identify precise proposals and general directions. The document aims to map themes introduced in the Blueprint against current law. The report examines ED's ESEA reauthorization proposal, comparing it to current law based on themes from the Blueprint. It is organized around College- and Career-Ready Students and Additional Cross-Cutting Priorities, drawing comparisons where possible. Some sections of the Blueprint lack direct comparisons to the ESEA. The Blueprint lacks detail for some elements compared to current policy in the ESEA. Additional sources like the FY2011 budget request were used for more information. A concise side-by-side comparison is provided in Table A-2 for key provisions. Table A-2 provides a summary of key provisions in the Blueprint, while Table A-3 examines the consolidation of programs proposed in the FY2011 budget request. Table A-4 looks at funding for ESEA programs not subject to consolidation, and Table A-5 lists programs slated for elimination in the FY2011 budget. President Obama and the Secretary announced an ESEA flexibility package for states, offering waivers from academic accountability, teacher qualification, and funding requirements. States can apply for waivers for school years 2011-2014, with an option for a one-year extension. SEAs must meet four principles for improving education to receive the waivers. The ESEA flexibility package offers waivers to states from academic accountability, teacher qualification, and funding requirements. States must meet four principles set by ED to receive the waivers, including college- and career-ready expectations, differentiated recognition, effective instruction support, and reducing unnecessary burden. As of December 2012, 34 states and the District of Columbia had received approval for the ESEA flexibility package, with more applications under review. The ESEA flexibility package offers waivers to states from academic accountability, teacher qualification, and funding requirements. Congress may override these waivers with new provisions in the future. The focus is on current law, not the details of the flexibility package. More attention has been on accountability in education over the past decade. The No Child Left Behind Act introduced new provisions for academic standards, assessments, and accountability in education. These strategies include developing clear academic standards, aligning instruction to these standards, and using test-based accountability to measure student progress. Schools are rewarded for boosting student achievement or face consequences for failing to do so. The No Child Left Behind Act held schools and states accountable for student academic achievement through state-developed standards and assessments in language arts and mathematics. States were required to set proficiency benchmarks for students, aiming for all students to reach proficiency by 2013-2014. Schools and LEAs were annually assessed on student proficiency, participation in assessments, and additional academic indicators. The Blueprint proposes changes to academic accountability requirements, including eliminating AYP, altering standards and assessments in language arts and math, and modifying actions for schools not meeting performance targets. The goal of all students reaching proficiency by 2013-2014 would be replaced. The Blueprint proposes changes to academic accountability requirements, including replacing the goal of all students reaching proficiency by 2013-2014 with the goal of all students being college- and career-ready by 2020. It focuses on using Title I-A funds for standards, assessment, and accountability, renaming the program College- and Career-Ready Students. The Blueprint emphasizes the need for state-developed, college- and career-ready standards and assessments, rewarding schools for progress, addressing low-performing schools, and closing achievement gaps. The Blueprint proposes changes to Title I-A accountability requirements, focusing on college- and career-ready standards. Prior to NCLB, states had to adopt standards and assessments in language arts and math at three grade levels. States had to develop curriculum content standards and academic achievement standards to be eligible for Title I-A grants. Under the NCLB, states were required to develop and adopt standards and assessments in mathematics, language arts, and science at various grade levels. Achievement standards with three performance levels were established for all students. The Blueprint proposed states to adopt state-developed standards in language arts and mathematics that progress across grade levels. States would now be required to adopt standards for grades 3-12 in language arts and mathematics, with assessments aligned to these standards. High school assessments would determine if students are college- and career-ready. States have the option to upgrade existing standards certified by a four-year public university system. The Blueprint requires states to adopt standards for grades 3-12 in language arts and mathematics, with assessments aligned to these standards. States can upgrade existing standards certified by a four-year public university system or work with other states to create common standards for college- and career-readiness. The new standards must be evidence-based to ensure students graduate high school prepared for college and careers. However, there is a lack of clarity on what constitutes career-readiness and how those standards would be established. The Common Core State Standards Initiative is a grassroots effort led by the National Governor's Association and the Council of Chief State School Officers to develop common standards for language arts and mathematics in grades K-12. Supported by 48 states and the District of Columbia, the initiative aims to build towards college- and career-readiness. States will have the option to adopt and implement these standards once the final version is released in 2010. Some states, like Massachusetts and Minnesota, have expressed concerns about the standards' quality. The Common Core Initiative aims to develop common standards for language arts and mathematics in grades K-12. States adopting the standards can add 15% to reflect state priorities. The federal government supports the initiative, which aligns with proposed Title I-A accountability requirements. States must also implement science standards and assessments. The Blueprint allows states to include science assessments in the accountability system, expanding beyond language arts and math. The proposal eliminates AYP, allowing states to create new accountability systems with assessments in various subjects. States must develop English language proficiency standards based on speaking, listening, reading, and writing domains. The Blueprint requires states to develop English language proficiency standards aligned with college- and career-readiness standards for ELLs. NCLB strengthened accountability provisions under Title I-A, requiring a single statewide system for all students. Under the ESEA, states must have a single accountability system for all schools and LEAs based on academic assessments and indicators. AYP is determined by student scores on state assessments and must include additional indicators like graduation rates for high schools and attendance rates for elementary and middle schools. The AYP calculations for schools and LEAs must be disaggregated by demographic groups, including economically disadvantaged students, LEP students, students with disabilities, and major racial and ethnic groups. To meet AYP standards, at least 95% of students overall and in each demographic group must participate in assessments, with required threshold levels of performance. States and LEAs must meet AYP standards by achieving required performance levels on assessments and other academic indicators for designated student groups. Annual report cards with academic achievement data must be disseminated, and states must submit reports to the Secretary for compilation into national and state-level data. ED has announced a shift away from using the current AYP system for identifying low-performing schools and LEAs. The Blueprint proposes a new accountability system that rewards schools for growth and success, with rigorous interventions for low-performing schools. States must have data systems to track progress in preparing students for college and career readiness, and make student performance data public. Unlike the current AYP system, strategies for improving schools would be determined at the local level. The Blueprint proposes public data on student performance in language arts, mathematics, and science, including graduation rates and college enrollment. Data must be disaggregated by race, gender, ethnicity, disability status, English learner status, and family income. This expands on current law which only requires graduation rates to be made public by subgroup. The Blueprint proposes collecting additional data on teaching and learning conditions, including school climate, attendance rates, disciplinary incidents, and survey data. This information would need to be reported regularly by states and LEAs to address gaps in performance between male and female students. The Blueprint proposes collecting data on teaching and learning conditions, including school climate, attendance rates, and disciplinary incidents. Student performance goals and measurement methods are outlined, with rewards for meeting targets and requirements for low-performing schools. Under current law, AYP standards aim for all students to reach proficiency by 2013-2014, with incremental increases in achievement levels over time. The Blueprint proposes replacing the goal of all students reaching proficiency in language arts and mathematics by 2013-2014 with the goal of all students being on track to graduate high school college- and career-ready by 2020. Performance targets would be based on the achievement and growth of all students in a school and in subgroups. Performance targets for the 2020 goal of all students being on track to graduate high school college- and career-ready would be established based on student achievement and growth, including graduation rates. States, LEAs, and schools meeting these targets would be recognized and rewarded. However, it is unclear who would set the targets, the level of achievement and growth required annually, and whether targets would be based on 100% college- and career-ready students by 2020. Additionally, accountability measures for states, LEAs, and schools during the transition to college- and career-ready standards are unclear. Under current law, the primary basic structure for AYP under the NCLB is specified as a "group status model." States set a threshold percentage of students at proficient levels each year for all student subgroups. Threshold levels are set separately for language arts and mathematics, and may vary by K-12 level. Averaging scores over two to three years is allowed for determining group achievement levels. The NCLB statute includes alternative provisions for schools that do not meet AYP requirements, such as a 10% reduction in the number of failing students in each group compared to the previous year. This adds a "successive group improvement" model as a secondary AYP model. Another AYP model is the individual/cohort growth model, focusing on the rate of change in achievement over time among the same students. In November 2005, a growth model pilot program was announced by the Secretary for up to 10 states to use growth models for AYP determinations. In December 2007, the cap on states participating in the pilot was lifted. In October 2008, regulations were issued allowing states to request authority to include student growth measures in AYP definitions. The Blueprint released by the ED in January 2009 discusses the use of growth models in AYP determinations. By 2010, 15 states had included growth models in their AYP definition. The Blueprint emphasizes the importance of considering individual student growth and school progress over time in evaluating performance. Currently, only a few states are using growth models in their AYP determination process. The ESEA establishes a system of rewards and sanctions to hold schools and LEAs accountable for their performance. States are required to establish Academic Achievement Awards Programs to recognize schools and LEAs that have closed achievement gaps or exceeded AYP requirements. Awards may also be given to teachers and principals. States can fund these awards by reserving up to 5% of Title I-A funding. The Blueprint proposes an increased focus on rewarding schools, LEAs, and states that meet performance targets, significantly improve student performance, close achievement gaps, and turn around low-performing schools. These entities would be referred to as "Reward" schools, LEAs, and states, with funds provided to design innovative programs for them. The Blueprint proposes rewarding schools, LEAs, and states that meet performance targets, improve student performance, and turn around low-performing schools. Rewards may include financial incentives, participation in communities of practice, and flexibility in using ESEA funds. Competitive preference may be given to Reward states, high-need LEAs, and schools in federal grant competitions. Reward LEAs would have flexibility in implementing interventions in their lowest-performing schools, but the specifics are not detailed. It is unclear if Title I-A funds would be used for innovative programs and rewards. Under current law, Title I-A schools not meeting AYP for two consecutive years are identified for school improvement. This designation requires developing or revising a school plan for improvement, with LEAs providing technical assistance. Schools in improvement status must allocate at least 10% of Title I-A funds for professional development. Students in these schools have the option of public school choice, allowing them to transfer to another public school within the same LEA that is not in improvement status. LEAs must provide transportation for students transferring to different schools and prioritize low-achieving children from low-income families. Lack of capacity cannot be used as a reason to deny transfer requests. Schools failing to make AYP for two consecutive years are identified for school improvement and must allocate 10% of Title I-A funds for professional development. Students in schools identified for a second year of improvement must continue to be offered public school choice. Students attending a school in its second year of improvement must be offered the option to transfer to another eligible public school within the same LEA. Low-income students at the school must also be given the opportunity to receive supplemental educational services (SES), such as tutoring, outside of regular school hours. SES can be provided by nonprofit or for-profit entities, or the LEA, unless deemed unavailable by the SEA. The SEA must maintain a list of approved SES providers for parents to choose from. LEAs may need to allocate up to 20% of their Title I-A grants for this purpose. If a school fails to make AYP for two years, it must be identified for corrective action, which can include replacing staff, implementing a new curriculum, or restructuring the school's organization. LEAs must provide technical assistance, public school choice, and supplemental educational services. If a school does not make AYP for a third year after being identified for school improvement, the LEA must plan for restructuring, which can involve reopening as a charter school, replacing staff, contracting with an education management organization, turning over to the SEA, or implementing a major governance restructuring. If AYP is still not met after another year, restructuring must be implemented. Sanctions can be delayed for a year if AYP is met or due to unforeseen circumstances. Failure to make AYP for two consecutive years may exempt schools from school improvement sanctions. AYP standards apply to all public schools and LEAs receiving Title I-A grants. States failing to meet AYP standards only receive technical assistance. The Blueprint introduces "Challenge" states, requiring specific assistance for lower-performing schools. The Blueprint introduces "Challenge" schools, which include the lowest-performing 5% of schools in each state based on student achievement, growth, and graduation rates. States must identify schools in need of specific assistance, with unclear requirements for identifying these schools. The lowest-performing 5% may include schools receiving Title I-A funds and non-Title I-A schools. Under recent changes to the SIG program, non-Title I-A secondary schools meeting specific criteria can now receive SIG funds. Challenge schools must choose one of four school turnaround models: transformation, turnaround, restart, or closure. Restrictions on model usage under SIG may not apply to Challenge schools. Reward LEAs have flexibility to implement different intervention models. The lowest-performing schools, known as "warning category," would receive assistance through research-based strategies. Another category, "Challenge schools," includes those failing to close achievement gaps, with no specific percentage limit. States and LEAs have flexibility in providing assistance, not limited to the four turnaround models. The Blueprint proposes identifying Challenge schools based on specific criteria, with no set percentage limit. LEAs would need to implement data-driven interventions to help low-performing students and close achievement gaps. Strategies like expanded learning time and public school choice would be available. The use of these strategies would become optional under the proposal. Challenge LEAs and states would also be subject to provisions outlined in the Blueprint. The Blueprint proposes identifying Challenge schools based on specific criteria, with no set percentage limit. Challenge LEAs and states could face significant governance or staffing changes if schools, principals, or teachers are not receiving necessary support. Restrictions on ESEA funds and potential collaboration with outside organizations to improve student achievement may also be imposed, with details unspecified. Under current law, there is uncertainty regarding the percentage of Title I-A funds that would need to be reserved to support Challenge schools, LEAs, and states in the warning category. Depending on the amount or percentage of funds reserved, schools and LEAs not in the Challenge or Reward categories may receive less Title I-A funding. Under current law, funds are not specifically available for capacity building at the state and LEA levels to assist failing schools. States can reserve 4% of their Title I-A funds for school improvement efforts, but these funds are not reserved for building the capacity of states and LEAs to help schools in need of improvement. The Blueprint allows states and LEAs to reserve funds for various purposes to assist schools in need of improvement, including supporting the adoption of college- and career-ready standards, using data to improve student outcomes, enhancing technology in instruction, coordinating with early childhood programs, implementing family engagement strategies, and improving student performance in high-need schools. The percentage of funding that may be reserved is not specified. The Blueprint allows LEAs to reserve funds for school improvement strategies and equitable distribution of effective teachers. "Reward districts" get flexibility with this reservation, but the percentage to reserve is unclear. LEAs no longer need to provide public school choice and supplemental educational services. Title I-A comparability requirement ensures equivalent funding levels in Title I-A schools compared to non-Title I-A schools in the same LEA. The Title I-A comparability requirement ensures that state and local funds are provided equally to schools receiving Title I funds and other public schools within the same LEA. It aims to prevent federal funds from simply replacing state and local funds for Title I-A schools. There are concerns about LEAs using Title I-A funds to subsidize general operations instead of enhancing services for disadvantaged students. The comparability requirement in Title I-A aims to ensure equal funding for Title I-A schools and other public schools within the same LEA. Many LEAs meet this requirement without comparing expenditures or resources between the two types of schools. However, the lack of comprehensive school-level budgeting and accounting systems makes it challenging to report detailed financial data for comparability. This raises questions about the significance of the requirement as currently implemented. The Title I-A comparability requirement aims to ensure equal funding for Title I-A schools and other public schools within the same LEA. Comprehensive school-level budgeting and accounting systems are needed to effectively implement this requirement. Data on per-student expenditures from state and local sources are required to assess comparability, with the Education Department focusing on collecting this information. The Blueprint outlines ED's focus on comparability issues, collecting data on school expenditures, measuring resource disparities, and providing flexibility to LEAs supporting disadvantaged students. States must administer assessments in language arts, mathematics, and science to determine AYP. The ESEA requires states to administer science assessments in three grade bands. Two grant programs support states in developing and administering these assessments. Current law provides funding for state assessments through formula and competitive grants. The competitive grant program, known as grants for Enhanced Assessment Instruments, aims to improve the quality, validity, and reliability of state assessments. These funds can be used to develop various types of assessments, including those for special populations like English language learners and students with disabilities. States would use formula funding to align assessments with college- and career-ready standards in language arts and mathematics, measuring student academic achievement and growth. The Blueprint aims to improve academic achievement through assessments aligned with college- and career-ready standards. States would use funds to develop various assessments in different subjects and for special populations. Formula funds would only be available to states implementing these standards. Competitive grants would support research and development of additional assessments in various areas. The Blueprint for improving academic achievement through assessments aligned with college- and career-ready standards does not specify changes to current ESEA assessment requirements. It continues to support assessing language arts, mathematics, and science at specific grade levels. However, the Blueprint does not address how to assess students with disabilities, leaving a gap in providing assessment options for those for whom the state assessment is not suitable due to their disability. The Blueprint for improving academic achievement through assessments aligned with college- and career-ready standards does not specify changes to current ESEA assessment requirements. It continues to support assessing language arts, mathematics, and science at specific grade levels. However, the Blueprint does not address how to assess students with disabilities, leaving a gap in providing assessment options for those for whom the state assessment is not suitable due to their disability. Options for two groups of students with disabilities are discussed: (1) students with the most significant cognitive disabilities (AA-AAS), and (2) students with disabilities whose disabilities may prevent them from achieving grade-level proficiency within a year but who do not have the most significant cognitive disabilities (AA-MAS). ED has indicated support for alternate assessments for students with the most significant cognitive disabilities (AA-AAS) but has not confirmed support for other students with disabilities (AA-MAS). Instead, ED stated that new state assessments developed through the Assessing Achievement formula grant program would consider the needs of students with disabilities. The Achievement formula grant program considers the needs of students with disabilities in assessment development. Federal funds are provided under School Improvement Grants to assist failing schools. The Blueprint proposal builds on changes to target funds on the lowest-performing schools. The ESEA authorizes a separate formula grant program for state School Improvement Grants to support school improvement activities. At least 95% of each state's funds are allocated to LEAs to serve schools in need. The School Improvement Grants program provides funds to LEAs to help schools in need of improvement, corrective action, or restructuring. States prioritize grants for schools with the greatest need and commitment to improving. Schools eligible for assistance under Title I-A that have not met AYP for two years or are in the lowest performance quintile can receive these grants. Each school served must receive at least $50,000 from the state. The School Improvement Grants program requires states to provide LEAs with $50,000 to $2 million annually, renewable for two years. Priority is given to the lowest-performing schools, defined as Tier 1 or Tier 2 based on specific criteria. The School Improvement Grants program focuses on the lowest-achieving schools, with Tier 1 and Tier 2 schools receiving funds for specific intervention models. Tier 3 schools may also receive grants based on state-established criteria. The program targets schools identified for improvement, corrective action, or restructuring, with a graduation rate below 60% or in the lowest-achieving 5%. The Blueprint proposes similar measures for low-performing schools as the School Improvement Grants program. States must allocate funds to LEAs committed to implementing one of four models in Tier 1 and Tier 2 schools: turnaround, restart, closure, or transformation. The turnaround model involves replacing the principal and providing more flexibility in staffing and budget. The Blueprint proposes measures for low-performing schools, including four models for Tier 1 and Tier 2 schools: turnaround, restart, closure, or transformation. The restart model involves converting or closing and reopening a school under new management selected through a rigorous process. The closure model requires closing a school and enrolling students in higher-performing schools within the LEA. The transformation model under the Blueprint requires implementing strategies to increase teacher and school leader effectiveness, using research-based instructional programs, increasing learning time, and creating community-oriented schools. The program would be renamed School Turnaround Grants under the reauthorization proposal. States would receive funds by formula and could reserve some funds to build state capacity for improving low-performing schools. The Blueprint proposes using funds to improve low-performing schools through various intervention models like transformation, turnaround, restart, and school closure. LEAs and nonprofit organizations could receive grants to implement these models for three years, with the possibility of two additional years of funding for schools showing improvement. The Administration proposes changes to the School Improvement Grants (SIG) program, including reserving funds for the Secretary to support activities to improve low-performing schools. States would be required to develop standards in language arts and mathematics for grades 3-12, continue annual assessments in grades 3-8, and create assessments for college- and career-readiness in high school. The proposal aims to replace the current AYP system with a new goal for all students to be college- and career-ready by 2020. There will be a focus on rewarding schools that meet performance targets, improve student performance, close achievement gaps, and turn around low-performing schools. Different categories of low-performing schools will have specific requirements for improvement, with continued funding and specific models for turnaround. The federal government historically had limited involvement in teacher policy, but with the No Child Left Behind Act, new provisions were added to ensure teacher quality. States and LEAs were required to develop plans to meet minimum teacher quality requirements by the 2005-2006 school year. The NCLB highly qualified teacher requirement shifted to focusing on effective teachers and leaders based on student academic growth. The Blueprint emphasizes federal teacher and leadership programs, particularly the ESEA, Title II-A, Improving Teacher Quality State Grants. The Blueprint emphasizes the importance of teacher and leader effectiveness, focusing on improving evaluation, rewarding effective educators, and strengthening recruitment and preparation programs. It aims to consolidate and refocus current programs to support teachers and leaders in providing effective instruction for all students. The ED proposes to rename the formula grants under ESEA, Title II-A to Effective Teachers and Leaders State Grants, focusing on improving school staff effectiveness. Grants are awarded to SEAs, which then distribute funds to LEAs based on a formula considering school-aged population and poverty levels. The Blueprint proposes a formula grant allocation to states based on school-aged population and poverty levels, with states required to subgrant at least 90% of funds to LEAs. The Secretary can reserve 1.5% of funds for national activities, and funds may also support continuation grants for various current programs. Quality Partnerships, Teachers for a Competitive Tomorrow, and Transition to Teaching programs under Title II-A focus on improving teacher quality through activities like professional development and class-size reduction. NCLB required core subject-matter teachers to meet new highly qualified teacher requirements by possessing a bachelor's degree and state teaching certificate. The Blueprint proposes the Effective Teachers and Leaders program. The Blueprint proposes the Effective Teachers and Leaders program, which would mandate reform of teacher and principal evaluation systems. It includes requirements for statewide definitions of effective teachers and principals, state-level data systems linking teacher preparation programs to outcomes, and district-level policies. The Blueprint proposes the Effective Teachers and Leaders program, which mandates reform of teacher and principal evaluation systems. It includes requirements for statewide definitions of effectiveness, state-level data systems linking teacher preparation programs to outcomes, and district-level evaluation systems that differentiate teacher and principal effectiveness in multiple performance levels. The majority of Title II-A funds are currently used for professional development, replacing class-size reduction as the largest area of spending. The Blueprint aims to improve teacher and leader effectiveness by reforming evaluation systems. Current professional development lacks effectiveness, with only 43% of teachers receiving more than 16 hours of training annually. The program also lacks teacher collaboration and curriculum development. The Blueprint seeks to address these issues by focusing on the outcomes of supported activities. The Blueprint focuses on improving teacher and leader effectiveness through enhanced evaluation systems. Grantees would develop fair and meaningful evaluation systems, provide collaboration and development opportunities, build instructional teams, and offer job-embedded professional development. These activities must align with evidence of student learning improvements and aim to distribute effective teachers and principals equitably. Districts with required evaluation systems may have flexible spending options. The Blueprint aims to improve teacher and leader effectiveness by requiring the publication of key indicators of program success in state and district report cards every two years. These reports must include information on teacher qualifications, effectiveness designations, support levels, working conditions, teacher and principal attendance, retention rates, and more. Additionally, the Blueprint proposes merging two competitive grant programs that reward teacher performance and career advancement. The Teacher Incentive Fund (TIF) and Advanced Credentialing programs will be merged into the new Teacher and Leader Innovation Fund, which supports teacher and principal compensation reform based on performance, student achievement gains, and leadership roles in challenging schools. The Teacher and Leader Innovation Fund merges the Teacher Incentive Fund and Advanced Credentialing programs to support compensation reforms, teacher and principal development, and evaluation. Applicants must demonstrate a significant investment in their project's sustainability. The Teacher and Leader Innovation Fund merges programs to support compensation reforms, teacher and principal development, and evaluation. States and districts can implement ambitious reforms to identify, recruit, prepare, retain, reward, and advance effective educators. Nonprofit organizations can partner with states and LEAs for grants under Advanced Credentialing and compete for an Innovation Fund grant. Existing competitive grant programs will be combined into a new program called Teacher and Leader Pathways. The Teacher and Leader Innovation Fund merges programs to support compensation reforms, teacher and principal development, and evaluation. States and districts can implement ambitious reforms to identify, recruit, prepare, retain, reward, and advance effective educators. Nonprofit organizations can partner with states and LEAs for grants under Advanced Credentialing and compete for an Innovation Fund grant. Five current competitive grant programs would be combined under this new program into two activities: Teacher Pathways and Transformational Leaders. The HEA authorizes grants to Teach for America, Inc. and the Teachers for a Competitive Tomorrow program to enhance teachers' content knowledge. The Blueprint aims to consolidate programs to strengthen pathways into teaching by providing competitive grants to prepare teachers for college- and career-ready standards. The Secretary may reserve up to 5% of funds for a national teacher recruitment campaign to recruit talented candidates into the teaching profession. The current School Leadership program assists high-need LEAs in recruiting, training, and retaining principals and assistant principals. The Blueprint under the School Leadership program aims to strengthen pathways into school leadership by providing grants to prepare principals for improving student outcomes in low-performing schools. It also focuses on conditions that increase success, such as autonomy over staffing and budget. Up to 5% of funds may be reserved for recruiting and supporting state and district leaders. The Administration proposes changes for teachers, requiring states to define effective teachers and principals based on student growth and other measures. States must develop district-level evaluation systems that differentiate effectiveness, provide feedback for professional development, and involve stakeholders. New indicators of program success would be published at the state level. The Blueprint proposes new indicators of program success in state and district report cards every two years. It merges existing grant programs into the Teacher and Leader Innovation Fund and Teacher and Leader Pathways. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act supports programs for student groups facing challenges in education. The Blueprint proposes to thematically group existing educational programs that support access to high-quality education for student groups facing unique challenges. These programs include support for migrant, neglected, delinquent, English language learners, rural education, Native American education, homeless students, and children connected with federal activities. The Blueprint aims to strengthen elementary and secondary education programs targeting diverse learners under the new heading of Meeting the Needs of English Learners and Other Diverse Learners. The Blueprint proposes to group existing educational programs supporting diverse learners, including students with disabilities, ELLs, migrant workers' children, homeless children, neglected and delinquent children, American Indians, rural area children, and children connected with federal activities. It highlights changes to ESEA programs related to diverse learners, emphasizing the importance of preparing all students for college or a career. The ESEA influences the education of students with disabilities by requiring their participation in state assessments and accountability systems. The Blueprint does not suggest changes for students with disabilities under a reauthorized ESEA. Title III of the ESEA mandates language instruction programs for limited English proficient students to meet state academic standards. The Blueprint proposal aims to establish consistent statewide criteria for identifying and placing LEP students in language instruction programs, addressing concerns about current criteria not considering various factors. This would require states to set criteria for both identifying and exiting LEP students from language programs. Under current law, SEAs can require failing LEAs to develop improvement plans if they do not meet their AMAOs for two consecutive years. LEAs failing for four consecutive years may face consequences such as modifying their language instruction program, fund withdrawal, and personnel replacement by the SEA. The Blueprint proposal suggests that LEAs consistently failing to meet their AMAOs would have less flexibility and be required to work with the SEA to implement more effective strategies. The SEA would provide a list of effective programs for the LEA to choose from. The Blueprint proposal would require states to create a system to evaluate the effectiveness of language instruction educational programs, increasing accountability for ensuring that LEP students are supported. States would provide a list of effective programs for LEAs to choose from, aiming to improve outcomes for English language learners. The Blueprint proposal aims to increase state accountability for LEP students' English proficiency and academic achievement. States must lead in improving language instruction programs, disaggregate LEP students by subgroups, and fund competitive grant programs. The Blueprint proposal includes a competitive grant program to support innovative programs for LEP students, such as graduate research fellowships and teacher preparation. The Migrant Education Program provides grants to SEAs based on the 2000-2001 count of eligible migrant children. The Migrant Education Program provides grants to states based on the 2000-2001 count of eligible migrant children, with adjustments made for inaccurate data. The program aims to assist states in improving coordination of educational programs for migrant students. The Blueprint proposal suggests updating the formula grant program with more accurate and timely data. The Education for Homeless Children and Youths program provides assistance to ensure homeless children have equal access to education. Grants are used for enrollment, attendance, and academic success, including tutoring and medical services. The Education for Homeless Children and Youths program provides assistance such as tutoring, medical services, and referral services. States must submit a plan to identify homeless children, ensure their participation in food programs, and address issues like transportation and immunization.
